title: 111_hr2313
content: The Act is titled the "U.S.-China Language Engagement Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The "U.S.-China Language Engagement Act" defines key terms such as elementary school, local educational agency, secondary school, state educational agency, physical exchange, Secretary, and virtual exchange. The "U.S.-China Language Engagement Act" defines terms for academic, professional, or cultural exchanges between the United States and China that do not involve international travel. SEC. 3. PROGRAMS FOR CHINESE LANGUAGE AND CULTURAL STUDIES INSTRUCTION. The Secretary of Education will award grants to local educational agencies for innovative Chinese language and cultural studies programs for elementary and secondary school students. Grants will be for three years and must demonstrate replicable approaches and may include professional development. The Secretary may reserve funds to evaluate program effectiveness and give special consideration to applications with intensive summer Chinese language instruction programs for professional development, including physical exchanges. The Secretary may reserve funds for program evaluation and prioritize applications with summer Chinese language instruction programs for professional development, including physical exchanges and promoting bilingualism, sequential Chinese language study, technology use, innovative activities, and a comprehensive approach to learning Chinese. Authorization of Appropriations: $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2014, and necessary sums for succeeding years. Amounts remain available until expended. The School Language Technology Enhancement program is authorized to receive funding of $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2014, and necessary sums for succeeding years. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies to improve Chinese language instruction through technology. Agencies must apply for grants and priority will be given to those using funds for virtual exchanges involving students. Local educational agencies receiving grants must use the funds to acquire communication technologies for collaborative ventures with foreign language centers and conduct virtual exchanges with schools in China. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. The Secretary is authorized to receive funds for fiscal years 2010 through 2013, with decreasing amounts in subsequent years. The appropriated funds are available until expended. Congress believes that increasing students' exposure to Chinese language and culture before graduating will boost the US's global economic competitiveness in the 21st century.
